body.p:
Some years since I have had the pleasure to receive by application
of Dr. Davids, at Amsterdam, from your hands the cadeau of two
valuable works, your Discourses and the Elements of Mos.Faith,
and I did not neglect to present to you my warm thanks for
this token of appreciation of the Yaavbacker?, of which I
was one of the editor. I never heard any tiding since
from you Reverend Sir, but never cease to read the
said works and wished to have occassions to renew
my thanks admitting the possibility you did not receive
my former letters.

Now that occassion presents itself by the
departure of the American Minister, Mr. Davezac,
who will be so kind to remit to you Rev. Sir, this
letter, which I am so bold to write in a language
which you writes with classical purity and elegance;
and which I understands as much to admire your
force of saying and your constant application to your
elevate task. I have been in the occasion last day to
admire that constancy the more, by some members of the
Occident, M. Laushery, merchand of this town, recently returned
from the United States, has given me to send, with some
num.'s also of the Asmonean. From those publications

I have had the great pleasure to perceive, the Jewish
life, is awaken in the other side of the Atlantic, and truly
I believe that by the nature of your institutions, by the great
outwanderings from Europe and by the development commerce
and discoveries have to be recently, the prospects of the Jews
in America are of the highest signification, in a moral and mate-
rial view both. Why the Isrealites may not taken their
part in the great movement of this century, ?
did in the 17?, principally on the soil of liberty and
colonisation, agriculture and commerce, you live upon?

I taken the liberty to present to you, Rev. Sir,
2 numbers of a publication of a Israel Society established
since two years in the Netherlands, or prove properly
in Holland, the country where the Jews enjoyed the
most true liberty and happiness, generaly speaking, after
the Union, and that you wl? have seen probably by
your going to the States.

The said Society promises to be a useful tie
to unite the orthodox and liberal amongst our people in this
country; and I am glad to tell you several Rabbies
of the most unflinching orthodoxy and liberals of the
most decided color, have given finally the hand eventually
to erect a bond of unity for promoting the moral
in material interests of the Jews in this country. You will
find the origin and prospects of this society in the 1st number,
and some valuable papers and particulars on
account of the Jews in Holl. and elsewhere in this periodical,
that, after a long interruption, had taken in now the
place of the yearbooken?.—I will not conceal to you,
Rev. Sir, that I am the autor of the paper, in Nr. 2, on
the Portuguese and German Jews in Holland, that I did written

to make some more ? between the two rites, and that I have
had the great pleasure to see well received by the Portuguese as well
as by the Germans. The union of both I believe will be of great profit for
the sake of our religion, but it is the work of time, it must not be
precipitated. I flatter myself you will find in this historical view
of the matter some particular unknown, deserving the attention of
the American Jews particularly.

I transmit you in the same time an ?, the traditions
with notes, of Mr. Anspachs brochure, edited in France some years ago:
le Croyant Israelite.

If there is an occasion for a regular change of your Occident, the
Asmonean, the publication of your American Is. society for diffusing knowledge, etc.
with the publications of our society, I hope you wil be so kind to
promote that object: the ties between the American Israel.s and the Dutch
will be by that way united more closely and it will be to the
benefit of both parts.

I cannot help ending with an other demand, somewhat
particular. From the list of subscribers to your valuable Discourses, I
saw confirmated what I did known en vague before, that some members of
my family are residing at Kingstown, Jamaica; if it is possible
and do not give to much trouble to you, will you have the kindness
to give me some information thereupon?—I am wholy to
your disposition for your interests, eventually, in this country, and I
hope to receive speedily some answer from your highly estima
ted pen. May Providence continue you, Reverend Sir, long in good
health to perform long time to come the task you have fulfilled
since twenty years already on the other side of the Ocean
for the good of Israel, Amen.
